questions.stem: Eastern (EEE), Western (WEE), and Venezuelan (VEE) equine encephalitides are BEST described as:

options.label: B
options.text: Arboviral encephalomyelitides affecting horses and humans

questions.explanation: EEE, WEE, and VEE are arboviral encephalomyelitides that affect horses and humans, causing inflammation of the brain and spinal cord. They are not pneumonias (A), fungal meningitis (C), or protozoal myeloencephalitis of ruminants (D).

questions.stem: The etiologic agents (EEEV, WEEV, VEEV) belong to which viral family and genus?
questions.explanation: These viruses belong to the family Togaviridae and genus Alphavirus. Orthomyxoviridae/Influenzavirus (A), Flaviviridae/Flavivirus (C), and Rhabdoviridae/Lyssavirus (D) refer to other pathogens.

questions.stem: What is the primary method of transmission of equine encephalitides to horses and humans?

options.label: B
options.text: Mosquito vectors transmitting virus from sylvatic reservoirs

questions.explanation: The viruses are transmitted via mosquitoes from sylvatic reservoirs (birds or rodents) to horses and humans. Direct contact (A), fecal-oral (C), or aerosol (D) routes are not the primary modes.

questions.stem: Which reservoirs are associated with EEEV and endemic VEEV respectively?

options.label: A
options.text: Birds for EEEV; rodents for endemic VEEV

options.label: B
options.text: Horses for both EEEV and endemic VEEV

options.label: C
options.text: Cattle for EEEV; dogs for VEEV

options.label: D
options.text: Reptiles for EEEV; pigs for VEEV

questions.explanation: Birds are the primary reservoirs for EEEV, whereas rodents serve as reservoirs for endemic VEEV strains. Horses are usually dead-end hosts except for epizootic VEEV (B), and other listed animals (C, D) are not the main reservoirs.

questions.stem: Which equine encephalitis virus can have horses as amplifying hosts during epizootics, posing a particular zoonotic risk?
questions.explanation: VEEV can mutate such that horses become amplifying hosts, with high viremia capable of infecting mosquitoes and then humans, creating a significant zoonotic risk in epizootics. EEEV and WEEV (A, B) maintain horses mostly as dead-end hosts.

questions.stem: Which virus is considered the most neurovirulent and rapidly destructive in horses?
questions.explanation: EEEV is the most neurovirulent and rapidly destructive, with very high mortality. WEEV and VEEV (B, C) are serious but generally less virulent than EEEV; WNV (D) is a flavivirus with different characteristics.

questions.stem: In which geographic regions are EEEV, WEEV, and VEEV primarily endemic?
questions.explanation: These viruses are endemic in North and South America. They are not primarily European/Asian (A), exclusively African (C), or Australian/New Zealand (D) diseases.

questions.stem: Which signalment factor increases risk of EEE in horses?

options.label: B
options.text: Young horses, especially under-vaccinated, in endemic areas with high mosquito density

options.label: C
options.text: Only draft horses in cold climates

questions.explanation: Young, under-vaccinated horses in endemic regions with high mosquito density are at higher risk, especially for EEE. Geriatric horses (A), only drafts in cold climates (C), or only breeding stallions (D) are not the primary risk groups.

questions.stem: During the prodromal (early) stage 48–96 hours before neurologic signs, horses with EEE/WEE/VEE may show:

options.label: B
options.text: Fever, depression, inappetence, and sometimes mild lameness or abdominal discomfort

questions.explanation: The prodromal stage often features fever, depression, inappetence, and sometimes mild lameness or abdominal discomfort before neurologic signs develop. Severe colic/diarrhea (A), respiratory-only signs (C), or no signs (D) do not fit the typical prodrome.

questions.stem: Neurologic signs of equine encephalitides typically include:

options.label: A
options.text: Somnolence, dementia, head pressing, ataxia, blindness, circling, seizures, and possibly weakness or paralysis

questions.explanation: Neurologic signs include somnolence, dementia, head pressing, ataxia, blindness, circling, seizures, and sometimes weakness or paralysis from diffuse brain (and sometimes spinal cord) involvement. Pruritus (B), pure respiratory signs (C), or isolated laminitis (D) are atypical.

questions.stem: Which additional clinical manifestations may be observed in severe cases?

options.label: A
options.text: Colic-like signs, reduced alertness, recumbency, and death

questions.explanation: Severe disease can progress to colic-like signs, reduced alertness, recumbency, and death. Solely dermatologic (B), laminitic (C), or ocular discharge (D) signs are not typical of terminal encephalitis.

questions.stem: In serologic diagnosis of EEE/WEE/VEE, which finding is considered confirmatory for recent infection?

options.label: A
options.text: IgM capture ELISA titer ≥400 or a fourfold rise between acute and convalescent samples

options.label: B
options.text: Single low positive IgG titer with no change over time

options.label: C
options.text: Negative IgM and no titer change

questions.explanation: An IgM capture ELISA titer ≥400 or a fourfold rise in titer between acute and convalescent sera supports recent infection. Stable low IgG (B), negative IgM (C), or fecal PCR (D) do not confirm infection in this context.

questions.stem: For EEEV specifically, how does the EEEV:WEEV titer ratio support diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A ratio ≤1 is strongly indicative of EEEV

options.label: B
options.text: A ratio ≥4 is suspicious and ≥8 is strongly indicative of EEEV infection

options.label: C
options.text: Only a ratio of exactly 2 is diagnostic

questions.explanation: An EEEV:WEEV titer ratio ≥4 is suspicious and ≥8 is strongly indicative of EEEV infection. A ratio ≤1 (A), exactly 2 (C), or disregarding titers (D) are incorrect.

questions.stem: Which CSF findings are consistent with arboviral encephalomyelitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Purely eosinophilic pleocytosis with low protein

options.label: B
options.text: Neutrophilic pleocytosis with elevated total protein concentration

options.label: C
options.text: Normal cell counts and proteins in all cases

options.label: D
options.text: Purely lymphocytic pleocytosis with low protein

questions.explanation: CSF findings typically show neutrophilic pleocytosis with elevated total protein, reflecting inflammation of the CNS. Eosinophilic (A) or purely lymphocytic with low protein (D) patterns suggest other etiologies, and normal CSF (C) is less consistent with active encephalitis.

questions.stem: Which disease is an important differential diagnosis for equine arboviral encephalitis because it can produce similar neurologic signs?
questions.explanation: West Nile virus encephalomyelitis is a major differential because it also causes viral encephalitis with overlapping clinical signs, although it often affects the spinal cord more prominently. Influenza (B), strangles (C), and sarcoids (D) involve different systems.

questions.stem: Which other conditions are included in the differential diagnosis list for acute neurologic disease in horses?

options.label: A
options.text: Rabies, leukoencephalomalacia (moldy corn poisoning), and hepatic encephalopathy

questions.explanation: Other important differentials include rabies, leukoencephalomalacia (from moldy corn), and hepatic encephalopathy, all of which can cause acute neurologic signs. Laminitis/colic (B), navicular (C), and ulcers (D) are not primarily neurologic.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST describes the treatment approach for EEE/WEE/VEE in horses?

options.label: A
options.text: Specific antiviral drugs are routinely curative

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment is primarily supportive: fluid and metabolic support, prevention of self-trauma, and sometimes corticosteroids

questions.explanation: There is no specific antiviral therapy; treatment is supportive with fluids, metabolic support, prevention of self-trauma, and sometimes corticosteroids in selected cases. Specific antivirals (A) and antibiotics alone (C) or NSAIDs alone (D) are insufficient.

questions.stem: Which mortality rates are MOST accurate for EEEV, WEEV, and VEEV respectively?
questions.explanation: Reported mortality: EEEV 85–100%, WEEV ~20–40%, and VEEV ~40–80%. The other figures (A, C, D) do not match the known pattern.

questions.stem: Why is vaccination critical in endemic areas for these viruses?

options.label: B
options.text: It significantly reduces the incidence and severity of disease and is the main preventive measure in horses

options.label: D
options.text: It only protects humans, not horses

questions.explanation: Vaccination is the main preventive tool, reducing incidence and severity and forming the basis of control programs in endemic areas. It does not eliminate mosquitoes (A), cure infection (C), or only protect humans (D).

questions.stem: What is the zoonotic potential of EEEV/WEEV compared to VEEV?

options.label: A
options.text: All three viruses make horses efficient amplifiers for human infection

options.label: B
options.text: EEEV and WEEV: horses are dead-end hosts; VEEV: horses can act as amplifying hosts and pose a greater zoonotic risk during outbreaks

options.label: C
options.text: None of the viruses have any zoonotic risk

questions.explanation: EEEV and WEEV make horses dead-end hosts (no significant viremia), whereas VEEV can create high viremia in horses, making them amplifying hosts and increasing zoonotic risk. All three do not amplify equally (A), and they clearly have zoonotic potential (C, D being incorrect).
